I read in an old astronomy book (The Origin and Evolution of our own Particular Universe) that talked about how Aristotle believed that the earth was the center of the universe and the planets orbited around us. When observation didn't match this model, Ptolemy decided that the planets moved in a circle upon a circle around the earth. A wheel upon a wheel, as he called it. This still wasn't quite right, and adding more wheels upon wheels upon wheels didn't work. It took until Copernicus for people to think we moved around the sun and Kepler to discover that the planets moved in ellipses, not circles. It's kind of funny to realize that the wheels upon wheels model was kind of right in a roundabout way, since we spin around on the earth, which spins around with the moon, with the whole affair spinning around the sun, which spins around the galaxy.

I wanted to take a moment to review Kurzgesagt as a whole. Why on this video? Because it is the most recent video of posting this. Kurzgesagt does an amazing job at taking science and showing it in a fun, and accessible way. I don't think I would be as interested in science as I am today. I have learned so much about space, the immune system, biological functions, diseases, fun experiments, etc through this channel. I have seen fun animations on such interesting topics, that would be so hard to research in the first place! I admire how much time, and effort goes into this youtube channel, your merchandise, and everything else. Kurzgesagt needs at least 20 million subscribers by the end of 12,022, and if they don't, I will dig myself to the center of the planet, build a black hole generator there, and kill the planet. Kay maybe not but I can pretend. I have never found a more consistent, and just fun youtube channel. You guys always thank us for what we are doing, but I have to thank you for just bringing science to an easy to understand format to over 18,000,000,000 people, and also I love the ducks. This video helps explain yet another reason why it is practically impossible for significant time travel.  We're constantly moving and accounting for exact x,y,z coordinates are impossible for significant time travel when we're the planet is rotating (nearly 1000 mph near equator), moving around the sun (around 66,000 mph), traveling around the Milky Way (rough estimate 500,000 mph), and moving through the universe relative to other galaxies (rough estimate over 1,000,000 mph), and all the other variables mentioned in the video.  A person/thing/atoms would be transported into some unknown coordinate and you'd have to know it to transport all the remaining atoms... unless you could do it a small bit at a time and account for previous transports... becomes exponentially complicated.

Stuff like this is why getting interplanetary trips with our current technology is a marvel of mathematics. We don't simply aim a spacecraft at a planet and have it coast there, we need to chart where the planet we're shooting will be in the months that it takes for the spacecraft to get there, and as this video shows, the movement of the planets relative to our own means such calculations become incredibly complicated really fast. It's especially marvelous when you consider that modern spacecraft only have enough fuel to get to their destination and perform course corrections; they're not cars where you keep the engine running all the way to your destination. Even the smallest course changes require expending precious fuel, and the smallest mistake can send your spacecraft wildly off course, which has happened to a good few space probes sent out over the years.

We have come a long, long way from when we believe everything in the universe revolved around us.
Heck, just a little over a quarter of a century ago (just 28 years ago!), there were many people walking around who firmly believed the only planets that existed in the entire universe were contained only within our own solar system....there was no solid evidence to the contrary. I was a grad student back in the early 90's and I knew many people who actually believed the only planets in our entire universe were only in our own solar system.
Personally, I think the discovery of exoplanets in 1994 is one of the greatest discoveries of the 20th century.....doesn't get the respect it deserves. Exoplanet discovery upended the belief system of billions of people world wide. It was an amazing discovery.

Imagine a static Frame of Reference. Just one person sitting on a chair in a featureless room.

We know time has a speed. It has a flow. Imagine an old analog clock, the minute hand spinning round and round. What is the speed of the flow of time?

It is the speed of light.

That person would age, eventually die and turn to dust in that featureless room. All the while traveling though time at the speed of light.

What’s cool is this helps grasp all the weird effects of traveling close to the speed of light.

It also helps understand why one can’t travel faster then light.

Having an arbitrary frame of reference is the most important part of existence. Without framing, it’s impossible to know anything. By knowing what’s around you, you can decide what to do. This gives you effectively unlimited possibilities for the point in time at which you exist, within the framework/rules reality follows.

While it may sound odd, being able to determine existence is far more valuable than we may consider, as we are able to add complex perspectives that can subvert our own. Objective perspective would be defined by divergence from normal, and would limit possibilities to only those which follow the fixed (or dogmatic) perspective.

Since perspective is based on principles and perspectives, we only need to operate within a lose framework, and that is what makes our lives most interesting—the ability to add things that are new, different, and better.

An empty universe has no dimensionality. In a universe without things, space does not exist. Likewise, in a universe without events, time does not exist. Spacetime owes its existence to the appearance of stuff and interactions of stuff within it. The attributes of stuff  (qualities we can measure) give rise to dimensions. All the attributes of stuff which we can perceive or measure (including but not limited to location in time and space) are relative with respect to the frame of reference of any observer. Everything is relative! This was outlined quite neatly by Walter Russell in "The Universal One" published in 1926.

This was a video about proper motion, not "where". There was hardly any "where" at all in this video, let alone "here" in relation to "there", which is what you said you were about to talk about and then failed to do so, rambling on about how the solar system is moving... Re-title: "The difference between classical orbits and what a real orbit might actually look like over distance in some direction"...

For those of you ACTUALLY curious about "where" you are: You are on what we have decided to call a 'planet'. In English, this planet is called Earth, in other languages it is named something different. From here on I will only reference English names. The nearest celestial body is The Moon. It takes about three days to get there without smacking into it and dying. We have to take a curved path to get there, so while the moon looks like it is one place, it is actually a little farther if you try to go there, and if you try to go where it is right now you will arrive at empty space. Next, we are in a complex system of objects orbiting a star. That means our "where" constantly changes, but we can rest assured that "right now" the sun is in a direction and the moon in some other direction, giving us a 'good enough' approximation to say we are between the sun and moon, as an example. Now, where is the solar system? The solar system is next to several different solar systems, but generally we just say stars to keep things simple. In reality, there is most likely a whole host of objects between us and the nearest star, so we could say something like, "The Solar System is on the far side of Alpha Centauri in relation to Sagittarius A*", as an example. Then we can ask "Where is our galaxy?". I'm not going to bother looking, but as an example, we could say something to the effect of "The Milky Way is part of a cluster of smaller galaxies that are moving towards Andromeda." This is loosely known as the Local Group which is moving towards "The Great Attractor". THEN you will have a rough idea of "where" you are.

P.S.

One thing that bugs me about time travel stories is the you not only have to very precisely calculate your trip through time, but also through space.
You have to do this with extreme precision because if you are off by a few meters in one direction you will find yourself far from the ground, or a few millimeters in the other actually IN the ground.
Earth's orbital velocity around the sun is, on average nearly 30 kilometers per second. But this velocity is not constant. The Earth speeds up and slows down depending if it is approaching aphelion or perihelion.
Also the moon is jerking it back and forth by many kilometers. If your calculations or precision is off by as little as 1000th of a second you could find yourself 30 meters above or below the ground. In either case you will soon be dead after your arrive at your destination.
And if you are moving through time at several hundred years at a time geologic processes need to be calculated.
And rarely geologic uplift or drop may happen very quickly (as in a few minutes). After a large Earthquake in the PNW in the 1700's the ground dropped 30 meters in just a few minutes.
In the movie Terminator 2, when Arnold Schwarzenegger appears in 1991 he leaves a small crater in the ground because they miscalculated slightly where the ground would be.
I would have loved to have seen the truck drivers reaction when he saw what had happened to his trailer.
You almost never see the fact that the Earth moves addressed in a time travel story.

This means that the cosmological principal is logically forbidden as it neglects the requirement that all possible solutions to any system of partial differential equations for any given initial conditions be *unique*. This means that within an infinite universe every possible path through space can never be the same as any other path they are all equally unique and this uniqueness encodes the past history of the universe and thus in turn the entropy of spacetime which for all nontrivial flat or open solutions must be nonzero everywhere(when) resulting in any initial anisotropies and inhomogeneities in the early universe effecting the metric at all possible scales that is to say the strength of gravity anywhere in spacetime depends on nonlocal hidden variables which amplify with scale ensuring logical consistency and causality holds at the cost of forcing the metric tensor to always be within the maximally nonlinear regime i.e. the Einstein field equations are always asymmetric appearing to be naturally consistent with the property of quantum entanglement as a nonlocal hidden variables. A.k.a. gravity== quantum entanglement of the wavefunction of spacetime so the assumption of the cosmological principal means neglecting path dependence of spacetime and thus violating the conservation of information which causes GR to become incompatible with Quantum field theory. Rejecting the cosmological principal appears to get rid of this problem and naturally leads to the quantization of gravity as well as eliminating several "crises in cosmology" such as the Hubble discrepancy the axis of evil problem and allowing the observation of net acceleration of spacetime to be naturally explained without the need to add some mysterious "dark energy" to the universe to force fit our models to observations. (Internally consistent solutions of the Einstein field equations always produce dark energy like effects because the Hubble rate can never be constant anywhere in spacetime for all possible logically consistent nontrivial solutions to the Einstein field equations.

Physics will only be able to progress again when the cosmological principal is finally allowed to die because mathematics requires internal consistency within any system of differential equations.

In astrophotography we have what's called galaxy season because the Milky Way is aligned with the horizon and the sky is wide open for deep sky objects. This is typically in Spring for the northern hemisphere, and in the Fall it's nebula season because the Milky Way is orthogonal to the plane of the horizon. This video also makes the galaxy/universe look much more full than it really is, which is chiefly nothing (but that would be boring).

The moon doesn't increase in mass as much as the Earth for obvious reasons. The older title of this video was "You Are The Center of The Universe" and I think this video encapsulates perfectly how pushing Copernican heliocentrism to its extreme brings back geocentrism. Modern Geocentrism and heliocentrism are both as accurate as each other because they use the same physics model with just a different frame of reference. We just swap between the two when it is convenient, but both frames of reference can perfectly co-exist, one at the level of intuition (when we get up and go to sleep) and one on the level of launching rockets into space. The sunrise in geocentrism isn't much different than looking at trees from a moving train. The train is your point of reference, and the trees are really moving, it's not an illusion because their position relative to yours is changing. If you want to say that they are really standing still, the only thing you're doing is jumping to another frame of reference. With that I mean that I find it a bit problematic to say that directions such as "up" or "down" is an illusion. The only logical conclusion from that is that your frame of reference is an illusion, but that's not true. Going a step further, that would mean that all frames of reference are illusions, but you need a frame of reference to work with reality, so you'd be shooting in your own foot. Anyway, that's my two cents. Great video!

The human knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the human from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.
In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation, the variation being the difference between where the human is, and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the human must also know where it was.
The human guidance computer scenario works as follows. Because a variation has modified some of the information the human has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it knows where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice-versa, and by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be, and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.

Some quibbles on an otherwise excellent video:
Empty space is not empty, and the universe is not a bag of things.
There is no such thing as "nothing" or "empty". (These are human concepts; a bias formed from our lifecycle.)
The "empty vacuum" of space is actually a very busy place. Empty space is filled with fields. Also: time itself.
Think of the universe not as a bag or container holding "things", but rather as an ocean with (possibly) infinite depths, and no surface.
The ocean is filled with currents (fields).
Eddies in these fields are, amongst other things, the particles that make up you and me.
This ocean is everything. It is all the things that have ever been, or ever will be.*
We don't know if the ocean is infinite in extent, or whether it curves back in on itself.
We don't know if the ocean had a starting point.
(Big Bang theory does not explain the start of the universe, only its evolution from a point about 14 billion years ago. Beyond that, the math doesn't work out. Our understanding is limited.)

*We don't know whether our universe is but just a part of a larger, eternal, infinite cosmos. One possible explanation for the apparent fine-tuning of our universe is that we occupy a bubble universe within a greater cosmos, alongside an infinite number of other bubble universes. In this theory, almost all bubble universes will be non-starters, having physical laws that prevent complexity arising that will make life like ours. But some universes (an infinite number, actually) will have initial starting conditions where eventual life is possible.

This is important to understand.  When people think about how an alien intelligence might detect us, they refer to radio waves created by humans gradually extending into space in an ever increasing sphere.  But it's not a sphere, is it?  It's more like a (jiggly) corkscrew funnel because the Earth has moved in relation to where the first signals originated, as has the sun and the solar system and the galactic arm and the galaxy itself.  So even if aliens detect our signals and deduce the direction they came from, they still have their work cut out to track us down.

Along similar lines ... I wonder how we measure distances on a universal scale.   For any ship to travel from earth to anyplace else, how do you accommodate for the fact that the place you left is no longer where it was when you arrive someplace else. And the place you arrive at is not where it was when you left. So how far did you go?  Indeed, at some point it seems silly to even try to calculate distance from your starting point (for example, if you are traveling light years). But I still wonder, how far did you go, how do you calculate it, and what does it mean. And if distance becomes a strange thing to measure how do you calculate direction and velocity?  And then of course, we have c which is supposed to be constant  But constant with respect to what - everything at the same time?  I find it hard to grapple with these ideas.

The first minute is or so is the real "braincrushing" and very well argued. The rest of the video is somewhat brutal in the sheer insignificance of our place in the universe--but at least it is somehow graspable. The first minute is not really graspable in the same way. Space is a wonderous concept in that it seem so intuitive and clear, yet, stops to have any meaning once you remove all "things". No one has ever measured space, let alone "seen" or "touched" it. Space by itself is not sound concept either philosophically nor phyiscally.

Yet, to this day, even well-trained physicists talk about mass "bending space-time" and "space-time" being the real thing and gravity only a property of its inherent shape. Yes, mathematically you can describe it in the abstract geometric manner. But the as video states very clearly--without things, space (or space-time) loses any meaning. Things and physical fields on the other hand are real and we have "positions" relative to each other. Now the consequence is, and this is the brain-crush, to let go of a "real" space-time in which we have those relative positions. It is not needed. We positions relative to other things. Full-stop. No space and time required. Space and time are, if you will, only the language we use to talk about these relative positions.

It is a little bit like we lose casual language too! The word "cat" is not the actual cat and no other word for "cat" is the cat. Remove all actual cats from our universe and these sounds stop to be words with meaning. Same is with "up" and "down" and "here" and "there". These words only have meaning because they refer to actual things relative to us.

The map of Earth is the way it is, not bcuz we simply decided that's the way we like to see it, but bcuz the planets have magnetic polarity, like a magnet.      Mangets have a north and south poles cuz the field flows in a specific direction from one pole to the other.      This is how we determine orientation.     Someone out in space will see the solar system and Earth rotating around the Sun and will appear basically as a disc formation, a specific orientation, due to the gravity/magnetic field of planet's with the Sun.

An interesting concept related to this is the issue of time travel. Even if time travel were to be possible, if you travelled back or forwards in time, you would also have to travel through space, as earth would be in an entirely different place, possibly millions of light years away considering the expansion of the universe. We often conceptualize time travel as if we could hop in a machine in our backyard, travel back in time to the era of dinosaurs, and see how our backyard looked back then. But you’d likely end up in an empty part of space with the Earth nowhere to be seen

I've wondered for a while; is it the case that an object can never reach absolute zero because its moving in relation to everything else? It always has momentum, even at the subatomic scale. What if it didn't; what if it all suddenly just stopped and the rest of its surroundings whipped past at millions of miles an hour as it kept right on going. What if even the protons stopped spinning and the electrons froze in place. Wouldn't that be true absolute zero? Complete subatomic stasis? And wouldn't it end due to the expansion of the universe pulling the quarks apart from each other? Wouldn't it have to exist outside of spacetime to stay at absolute zero?

You're in the center of the observable universe. You can only ever see a maximum distance away from you no matter how good your magnification, x-ray vision, or other techno/magical whazzits that let you see in every direction at once. Its relative to you specifically. But it's also delayed slightly as the light gets converted to electrical signals in your head and translated into something useful by your brain, so you're always seeing the past anyway. Your brain just kinda guess about what's where when as it goes along using past data as a series of reference points. But you're never where you think you are; you're actually a micosecond or something past that. You can only ever know where you were through empirical observation. You'll need to do some math and guesswork to know where you are.

I’ve been asked this question countless times “why is there something rather than nothing?” I’m so sick of it. Let’s say one of two options is upon us. Either there is something or there isn’t. Well let’s say both options are equally possible. If they are equally possible then they both happened... don’t believe me? There EXISTS a universe of nothing, but... that’d just be nothing. It does exists because it doesn’t. And there EXISTS a universe of something! The one we inhabit. Therefore both happened simultaneously!

There is something because both of two options came to fruition. We get to discuss it because we are in the universe of something.

I'm sitting outside watching this on my phone. It made me think of 20 years or so ago when I was in 8th grade. I borrowed my mother's boyfriend's little portable tv with a built in antenna and 3 inch very pixelated screen. I skipped school and watched tv out in the woods that I walked through to get to school. I remember watching the Super Mario Bros Super Show on it, as well as some other shows that the antenna picked up over the air, though tv during school hours was terrible after about 9am.

I brought extra batteries because the tv ate up like 4 AA batteries in an hour or two. Now, instead of gobbling up batteries for a pixelated screen picking up only like 5 stations, in watching whatever i want from all around the world on a crisp 1080p display with like 400 pixels per inch which is way more pixels per inch than the old portable tv had in total on its little screen.

That was a nice little 90's gadget and that was when I discovered my love for sitting outside in the nice weather and watching tv/videos and also listening to my cd player, which now is also replaced by my phone which has basically every song I could ever think of instead of just whatever cd I had in the player (which also ate batteries at a crazy fast rate so I had to replace them at the very least every few days).

It's just incredible how much has changed since 1999 or so. It makes me appreciate my phone so much more. It's a tv, radio, comic reader, book reader, game player, compass, flashlight, notebook, communication device, a video and picture camera, and more all in 1. Just to get even close to this 20 years ago I would need a ton of batteries, a portable tv, a portable cd player or radio, actual comics, actual books, a Gameboy, an actual compass, an actual flashlight, a gigantic phone or more likely a beeper, a huge camcorder, a camera, and a whole bag just to keep the stuff in while I carried it.

Do we even appreciate how bright modern phone flashlights are compared to the old flip phone terrible flashlights? I could barely use a flip phone light to light up the path going through the woods and now my phone can light up half a damn forest on the lowest brightness setting. It's just such a handy tool and it didn't even need batteries, it has a rechargeable one built in that i can charge with a portable solar battery charger that can get you an hour or 2 of screen use with a full day of sunny charging. It's just mind blowing how many utilities are right in our pockets everyday.

Just a some thoughts for passing readers to appreciate.

Well, the problem is 'up' is inherently relative. I can't be defined in absolutes. So it's always what a person sees as up. Put someone in zero gravity and a featureless room. 'Up' for that person will always be in reference to their head, until they see something else in the area that gets them to adjust their reference to match... say they see a sign and rotate themselves to match. They've simply changed their definition of 'Up' to make things easier.

So really, 'Up' doesn't need to be right or wrong. 'Up' is what works best for you and those you want to work with. And you would be amazed at how many 3D modellers and mechanical engineers struggle with this basic concept.

fun story: i grew up in a town on a longi lake, my mother is originally from a town further up the lake, or at least that's how she would describe it because the water flows in a particular direction meaning the town she's from is at a higher altitude. me on the other hand says we should go "down" to her home town because looking at a map this town is to the south of us. my mom often said that my perspective is wrong and i explained to her that i and many younger people think more globally and use the map as frame of reference and not local geography. my mom completely disagrees with this frame of reference and thinks its wrong and that i'm silly (we've had this argument many many times over the years).
last weekend it was my best friend's stag weekend and we had a dinner with the bridesmaids. one of them overheard me making reference to this concept and asked me to repeat it. she then agreed that "yes of course i too think n0orth is up and south down and oh right hmm yes yes i see the flowing water higher altitude that does make sense but noi see north as up and south as down." i used to think that this idea was heavily influenced by my video game habbits but this woman is no gamer at all which are plus points to the idea that it's a generational thing.

A person knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The brain uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the person from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is.

At 3:48, it seems the planets resemble, atoms; as we know them today.
What makes us think that there aren't organisms living on atoms?!
With that in mind, it stands to reason that the universe is as large, as it is small.
If we assume that atoms like planets, then there could be even smaller organisms living on electrons, protons, and neutrons, believing them to be planets. And those organisms are composed of even smaller particles (much smaller atoms - micro atoms, if you will).
From a macro scale, planets and solar systems as we know them, could comprise molecules, making us a tiny piece of a bigger organism.
We, in turn, could be a tiny part of a bigger collection, making a cell, molecule, system.
The universe is as large, as it is small - infinite.
We may never truly know where we stand in the grand scheme of things.

here comes my dose of existential crisis

You see, this I know to be true.  I've always had a good sense of direction and knowing roughly where I was.  I just thought it was something natural, an internal compass if you will.   Then, on the saddest day of my life, my mother passed away.  When I heard the news it hit me like a brick, even though she had been unwell for some time and it was somewhat expected.  All of a sudden I had a feeling I'd never experienced before.  I felt lost.  Even though I knew exactly where I was.  It's hard to explain but the best I can describe it was a sensation of floating weightless in a void or in the middle of some calm, vast ocean not connected to anything and drifting aimlessly with no sense of where I was, or was going.  After the funeral services I was at the dinner we had at my oldest brother's house and I was watching my kids play with their many cousins, Aunts, and Uncles.  I noticed that slowly I began to regain my feet, and bearings.  It was then that I realized, I had always known where I was because I knew where she was.  She was my connection to the world and universe.  It had now passed to my kids, the only others I had that type of bond with.  It was a strange experience that made me wish I'd made the connection before.  But I never knew that was it until it happened.

That'd be like an amoeba trying to exist in our world. I personally hope for a "Star Trek" future, but I know too much and by all accounts, such a thing is likely going to always be practically impossible. The best and most we could hope for is maybe colonizing our own solar system, and same goes for any and all aliens out there too. And if a biological species ever beat the odds to survive long enough, and becomes "transalien" enough to alter themselves to the point where they could exist in space, then they'd basically become the Combine from HL2, cybernetic space whales, hive-mind AI cluster ships, or some other kind of cosmic horror.

Just some alien dude walking around a spaceship is fiction sadly. Our universe/reality doesn't work that way. In order to ever reach intergalactic civilization levels biological life would have to fundamentally alter themselves, and I think that is the Great Filter.

There is a small but significant error at 3:10. The visual shows the semi-major axis of the orbit decreasing, but that is not what happens. The semi-major axis is always constant to within a rounding error, except perhaps on the scale of hundreds of millions of years. Rather, it is the semi-minor axis that changes with the eccentricity. This means that the average distance from the sun (which equals the semi-major axis) and the length of the sidereal year don't change, but the variation in distance does change.

When we say the solar system is orbiting around the center of the galaxy at x speed, what is that speed in reference to? Speed, just like position/displacement, needs to be in reference to a fixed point, line, plane, etc. --- so if there's no fixed object in the galaxy, how is that speed even approximated? Who's to say our solar system isn't traveling really slowly, and the other systems around us are what are traveling quickly? Same question for the "speed" that Voyager I is traveling at: relative to what, exactly?

I've been thinking a little bit about the whole relative-to thing.

I'm no physicist, but I hear occasionally physicists talking about how 'the math just comes together' if they assume the Universe has an extra dimension. And so I thought one day "well, we need the position of another thing to know our own position in 3D space - what if the extra dimension really does exist as that other thing?"

I mean, I thought about it for 10 minutes before scratching my backside and grunting about the TV remote, anyway.

Funny enough, most of what is explained here is why to me Time Travel seems like an impossible task. IF one would have to calculate where a place is at any given time in existence, and all of the universe is always spinning in orbits around one another, we just know too little to pin point the location in time to jump to that timeline.

In other words: You might jump through time and end up in the middle of space, because the WHERE changes alongside unknown variables, so you only really know the WHEN.

This is the sort of thing I think about when the idea of being able to teleport enters my mind. Imagine most power fantasies where people have superpowers. There is one person with the power to be able to teleport from one point in space to another. They better hope that their power takes gravity into the equation or they might just end up halfway across the galaxy or universe. There is a superhero named Lemellion in the anime My Hero Academia. His power basically lets him phase through things like matter and energy. He can walk throw walls and isn't affected by light while using his power. Thankfully for him, it seems he is still affected by gravity since when he uses his power he is usually pulled down towards the center of the earth and shot back up when he stops using his power. Hypothetically I imagine that if he wasn't still affected by gravity then if he used his power for even just a few seconds he might find himself stranded in or even out of the solar system given how fast everything moves relative in the universe.

As an example will just consider the speed of the solar system itself, ignoring the speed of the milky way and larger-scale clusters. It is estimated that the solar system is moving around the center of our galaxy at about 220 kilometers per second or 490,000 miles per hour. Assuming this is correct then with some math, we can say we (The solar System) are moving about 136 miles per second. So if someone with the power to ignore gravity and phase threw matter and energy used that power for even just one second the solar system would move 136 miles away from them, since they are not affected by the gravity of earth or the rest of the solar system. This is just a super basic way of explaining my thoughts cause it would be way more complicated if we took in all the factors and the speed of everything in the universe. But it's just a neat and fun idea, though it might be flawed idk.

Officials on the council thanked practitioners for providing the information, which helped them to understand the importance and urgency of the situation.


Two practitioners spoke at the Middlesex County council meeting on August 3, 2021.

The council passed the resolution on August 3.

Chairman of the Board: A Truly Sad Situation

Wayne H. Jessie is the Chairman of the Board of Supervisors in Middlesex County

Wayne H. Jessie, Chairman of the Board of Supervisors, said he was unaware of the forced organ harvesting by the CCP from Falun Gong practitioners and prisoners of conscience.

“The CCP is inhumane to do this to its own people. It is really tough to think this kind of thing is happening, I cannot imagine any human being will do this to another person,” he said. “But it is happening in a communist country which is very, very disturbing and very sad.”

I was watching a funny cat video and a cat was looking at birds on a tv as if the birds were real. It occurred to me that the cat knows what birds look like, but has no understanding of what a tv or video is. What if we humans were similarly limited in our understanding of what we perceive. What if when we look at 'the universe', what we are seeing is the equivalent of a video clip? We wouldn't know where we are because we wouldn't know where  'where' is. The cat may see a bird sitting on a tree branch, but there is only a flat video image. There is no tree and no bird. We may see planets and galaxies but there might not be any planets or galaxies.

The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.
In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation, the variation being the difference between where the missile is, and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the missile must also know where it was.

You missed an important detail at the end. The observable universe does have a well defined reference frame in the isotropic CMB frame.

It represents the frame in which the average velocity of observable matter is zero, such a frame must exist as otherwise everything would have to move with infinite velocity

The milky way is moving at roughly 600km/s in that reference frame, so you can add that as the final velocity component

Science Breaking News: “Kansas is Actually Flatter Than A Pancake” by Erin Podolak ~ Tuesday, August 16th 2011. As the old saying goes Kansas, like many midwestern states, is as flat as a pancake. Somehow, pancakes became the golden standard for flatness, but do they really deserve such a title? A team of researchers from Texas State University and Arizona State University decided to find out. The researchers scientifically tested whether or not the state of Kansas was as flat as a pancake, and were surprised at what they found. Pancakes might be flat, but they are by no means the golden standard. The state of Kansas is actually flatter than a pancake. Who would have thought that was possible? The researchers figured this out by gathering data from the US Geological Survey about the topography of Kansas. They then obtained sample pancakes from none other than that breakfast staple, The International House of Pancakes. Armed with science and breakfast, the researchers headed into the lab. The researchers used a confocal laser microscope to compare the flatness quotient of a pancake to the USGS data about Kansas. For something to be perfectly flat (1.0) it would need to have no two points on its surface at different levels. A 2cm strip of pancake was placed under the microscope, and the researchers found that it was surprisingly inconsistent (0.957) with some sharp peaks and a lump in the center. Kansas, on the other hand, was pretty darn close to the perfectly flat designation, coming in at 0.9997. According to the researchers, this makes the state flatter than a pancake. Now, this isn’t to say that Kansas is as flat as it gets, as it does fall short of perfect and there are bound to be some hills or other “spikey” things that would keep it from that designation, but the researchers were able to conclude that a pancake is shockingly bumpy and doesn’t deserve to be the golden standard for flatness.

We can feel the slightest breeze on a summer’s day, but never one iota of air displacement from these incredible speeds! “The distance across St. George's Channel, between Holyhead and Kingstown Harbour, near Dublin, is at least 60 statute miles. It is not an uncommon thing for passengers to notice, when in, and for a considerable distance beyond the centre of the Channel, the Light on Holyhead Pier, and the Poolbeg Light in Dublin Bay. The Lighthouse on Holyhead Pier shows a red light at an elevation of 44 feet above high water; and the Poolbeg Lighthouse exhibits two bright lights at an altitude of 68 feet; so that a vessel in the middle of the Channel would be 30 miles from each light; and allowing the observer to be on deck, and 24 feet above the water, the horizon on a globe would be 6 miles away. Deducting 6 miles from 30, the distance from the horizon to Holyhead, on the one hand, and to Dublin Bay on the other, would be 24 miles. The square of 24, multiplied by 8 inches, shows a declination of 384 feet. The altitude of the lights in Poolbeg Lighthouse is 68 feet; and of the red light on Holyhead Pier, 44 feet. Hence, if the earth were a globe, the former would always be 316 feet and the latter 340 feet below the horizon!” -- Dr. Samuel Rowbotham, ~ Earth Not a Globe!



“The lights which are exhibited in lighthouses are seen by navigators at distances at which, according to the scale of the supposed ‘curvature’ given by astronomers, they ought to be many hundreds of feet, in some cases, down below the line of sight! For instance: the light at Cape Hatteras is seen at such a distance (40 miles) that, according to theory, it ought to be nine-hundred feet higher above the level of the sea than it absolutely is, in order to be visible! This is a conclusive proof that there is no ‘curvature,’ on the surface of the sea - ‘the level of the sea,’- ridiculous though it is to be under the necessity of proving it at all: but it is, nevertheless, a conclusive proof that the Earth is not a globe.” -- William Carpenter,

100 Proofs the Earth is Not a Globe
Surveyors, engineers and architects are never required to factor the supposed curvature of the Earth into their projects. Canals and railways, for example, are always cut and laid horizontally, often over hundreds of miles, without any allowance for curvature. (self.conspiracy)



The London and Northwestern Railway forms a straight line 180 miles long between London and Liverpool. The railroad's highest point, midway at Birmingham station, is only 240 feet above sea-level. If the world were actually a globe, however, curving 8 inches per mile squared, the 180 mile stretch of rail would form an arc with the center point at Birmingham raising a full 5,400 feet above London and Liverpool. Adding the station's actual height (240 feet) to its theoretical inclination (5,400 feet) gives 5,640 feet as the rail's necessary height on a globe Earth, more than a thousand feet taller than Ben Nevis, the tallest mountain in Great Britain.



The Suez Canal which connects the Mediterranean Sea with the Gulf of Suez on the Red Sea is a clear proof of the Earth's and water's non-convexity. The canal is 100 miles long and without any locks so the water within is an uninterrupted continuation of the Mediterranean Sea to the Red Sea. When it was constructed, the Earth's supposed curvature was not taken into account, it was dug along a horizontal datum line 26 feet below sea-level, passing through several lakes from one sea to the other, with the datum line and the water's surface running perfectly parallel over the 100 miles. The average level of the Mediterranean is 6 inches above the Red Sea, while the flood tides in the Red Sea rise 4 feet above the highest and drop 3 feet below the lowest in the Mediterranean, making the half-tide level of the Red Sea, the surface of the Mediterranean Sea, and the 100 miles of water in the canal, all a clear continuation of the same horizontal line! Were they instead the supposed curved line of globe-Earthers, the water in the center of the canal would be 1,666 feet (502 x 8 inches = 1,666 feet 8 inches) above the respective seas on either side!

Wow great video! I just realized you can also apply this to time your position in time. Because, when taking infinity into account, a postion in time can only be determined in relation to a period of time as well.
To me as an atheist, the philosophical realization from this is that you can give your life more meaning by changing the time frame to which you compare yourself.
Death gets really scary when you view yourself in relation to a larger timespan because only then you take into consideration the amount of time that is yet to pass, when you are no longer alive. But to you as an individual the most important temporal reference point should be your own lifetime. You can ignore what happens after that because you will not experience it anyway. If you view yourself in relation to your own lifespan, from that perspective your death is the equivalent the end of the entire universe.
At least to me, death is less scary if you think of it that way.

One of the nifty thing the video doesn't touch on is that while as far as we know all positions and orientations are equivalent, as the entire observable universe started from what we can't distinguish from the point, meaning every point in space used to be right next to every other, the velocity is another matter. From the fundamental physics perspective, there is still no absolute frame of reference for velocity, but we can measure the average velocity of everything. Because the momentum is conserved, a point that remained at rest from the moment of big bang, would observe uniform cosmic background radiation from all direction. But it's not. The radiation is very slightly hotter on one side, corresponding to red shift. And we can measure it very precisely. So precisely, in fact, that we know that the Solar System is moving relative to all of cosmos at a speed of about 369.8 km/s give or take just about 0.11km/s or less than 400km/h (!250mph) uncertainty.

Elite Dangerous as a game has incredibly detailed and animated stars and planets and let's you zoom around in a space ship. In VR you literally pilot them from the Captain's seat and you can get an incredible sense of scale as you travel across the galaxy to map stars, planets, or just visit outposts. ~ The best way to visualize ourselves in a static or dynamic inertial frame reference is to think about our absolute, relevent, & relative speed compared to anything/anybody else.
All objects/observers in space/time travel at different or at the same speeds, from the fastest to the slowest.
All object/observers that appear still/stopped are traveling at the same speed as we are, which is perceived as a stable/static inertial frame reference.
When an object/observer is traveling at a different speed other than we are, then it is considered a dynamic inertial frame reference.
* REM:
~ Referring to the Doppler Effect, this means that objects/observers that are approaching towards us, appear larger as they come closer, & they audibly sound at a higher pitch & increasing volume as well.
~ Objects/Observers that are at the same speed as we are appear still/stopped, relative to our position, with their size & audible qualities at actual dimensions.
~ When objects/observers are traveling faster than we are, they are receding away from us, & their appearance appears smaller & smaller, with their audible sound diminishing at a lower pitch & a lower volume.
* A great example is one of an observer at a train station.
~ As the arrival train approaches the boarding platform, it appears to become larger & it's announcement whistle become louder & sounds like it's getting closer.
~ When it comes to a full stop, then it's appearance & audible qualities are at it's actual dimensions.
~ Then as it is departing, it's appearance becomes smaller & smaller, & it's departure whistle becomes lower in pitch as well as lower in volume.
* When we find ourselves in the middle of nowhere out in the void of space & time without a material/time reference point, we are indeed still inertially relevant & relative to it, since we are now traveling at the same speed as it is.
Which is why, at first, one may get the temporary perception feeling of being lost, because our static/dynamic inertial frame reference perception is simultaneously coming from all sides/directions, & we had previously become accustomed to using fixed spatial/temporal reference points.
But now as we become more accustomed to being lost, then we will eventually & perceptually accept then we are indeed lost, which is a good thing, because then we will find ourselves creating/conceiving & becoming accustomed to a new fixed spatial/temporal reference point, even if it is one that comes from all directions.

The little prince reference at 2:29, brings back memories.

IF you were out in empty space
and there was nothing in the universe but you - no frame of reference
and you held a can of compressed air out at arms length, with both arms extended
turned the can at a right angle and released the compressed air
you would start to spin on the axis running thru your head and feet, like an ice skater spinning on the ice

there would be no reference point, because there is nothing in empty space to see
but with your muscles relaxed your arms would be pulled outward by the centipedal force

if you pulled your arms in to your chest, you would spin faster - pushing them out you would spin slower

but spinning relative to WHAT? to empty space - and the pull on your arms would tell you that you are spinning
relative to..... nothing!

let go of the empty can of compressed air and it will appear to fly away from you, in a spiraling orbit around you - getting farther and farther away
in reality the can will fly away from you in a straight line, but since you are spinning it will appear to be following a spiral

dont think about this for too long, or blood will start gushing out of your nose

so... here is the cosmic question - if you - alone in empty space - can only tell you are spinning by the centripetal force on your own body
how do we know if all the galaxies in the universe are also spinning, relative to their point of origin at the big bang
causing the universe to appear to be expanding... at an accelerated rate? 😮

If the entire universe is spinning, with no external reference point, the only way we could tell would be the presence of the centipedal force.

I'm pretty sure it will be common knowledge in a hundred years the mechanism by which we are able to see beyond the curve of the Earth. My theories lie in atmospheric lensing/gravitational lensing. My mind sees it logical that the our illuminated atmosphere would be sufficient to explain seeing cities well beyond the curve. But I also feel if it were a phenomenon that simple, it would have been known by now. This tells me that it's not the whole story, and as we know, gravitational lensing can amplify objects of great distance. What if our own planet's gravity, in conjunction with it's atmosphere and the lenses of our eyes, creates the illusion of a flat plane- even though we know the world is round. Small minds can't rap their head around the contradiction here. Flat earthers are right. The Earth does appear, at ground level to the individual observer, to be flat. But not because it is. This can be proven simply by contacting another "flat earther" 80 miles or more due south of you to plant a 3 foot stake in the ground at noon. After being sure it is completely level, With a compass and tape measure, record and compare notes. The math will prove that the Earth is indeed a sphere. But to the human eye, aided or unaided, through atmospheric/gravitational lensing- (I don't have the language to express the physics) it appears flat.

Excellent new video! Anyone else notice that cute lil reference to the little prince?! I didn’t see anyone mention it in the comments I read, lol. I wrote a poem once loosely referencing the concept in this video…here it is:

CONFETTI OF EXPERIENCE

Last night I dreamed in vivid truth
That time was not strictly linear
But, much like an infinite drill,
Was driving its way through space.

All the planets corkscrewing
Around the stars in each galaxy,
And each galaxy spiraling through
The darkened web of the universe.

My soul or base self, I observed
As hurling confetti of experience
In the whirlwind of my life, inside
The elevator shaft of my birth.

The ground floor I imagined
As a market of odd machinery
Operated by timeless beings
Skin and hair of weathered earth.

Delving further down into depths
Of lawless space, before light itself,
And those titans lay young, smooth
As river rocks in dawn’s basement.

In sleep, in dreams and visions,
There was the possible reinvention
Of events told in reverse order,
And reviewed by my future self.

The story of my life is like a tower;
One moment after another stacked
Toward the summit of my death, yet all
Visible, scaled or descended at once.

They work in many coordinate systems: Global, Local, Tool, Target, Object; and the freedom of movement is considered in both polar and xyz coordinates, sometimes both at the same time; even speed of movement, whether they are linear or joint, millimetres or degrees changes. Then add on top of that a moving platform on which the robot is or rotating systems and you got yourself something to think about.

Question about first part of a video. Imagine two objects, one is orbiting another. Time flow for a orbiting object is slower, but why? If something can be measured only relative to something else and not space itself, then first object is orbiting second just as second is orbiting first. But only one of them has slower flow of time.
Now take that knowledge and imagine two objects. We apply some acceleration to both, so we know, that both are moving in what direction. We know flow of time for both. Now we will slow one down - time flow for it will speed up. And we will continue to slow it down (apply opposite acceleration). Will time flow for it reach millions of years per one second on the other object? No. Why? Because "faster object" is faster relative to space-time, and not other objects, and flow of time for object is relative to space-time too. So when flow of time will no longer speed op and will start to slow down again then we will know - slower object has 0 speed on that axis relative to space-time itself. Doing so with 3 axis will allow us to pinpoint object to space.

Right off the bat: I'm religious – Christian, and I'm not here to push ideologies, so please don't heat things up in the comment section (though I'd be willing to "calmly" explain a thing or two if asked "calmly")...

Back to the bit from the video... Imagine what it would be like if a being, capable of having imaginations and mapping them in arbitrary (but traceable) positions/neurons in its mind, existed, but on a level far beyond human, a being whose imaginations could actually create tangible life and environment, with other sentient beings living said life — that's pretty much what I saw in that frame 🥺, a decent (but not necessarily complete) representation of what "God's" relation to the universe could be like (and, again, you don't have to treat this as something true, but it sure is fascinating to imagine a being so intriguing)

The Olmec calendar, Mayan, shows our solar system crosses the "Eye of the great serpent", the thirteenth constellation, every 630,000 Earth years accounting for nine years in the "eye". Funny thing is if a galactic year is 230,000,000 Earth years and we cross the galactic plane every 630,000 Earth years, then we cross the plane 365.08 times a galactic year. There are 365 solar days to one galactic year. Hold on there's more. One zodiac year is 25,772 Earth years. If you divide a solar day, 630,000 by a zodiac year 25,772 you get 24.44 zodiac hours to one solar day.

You couldve gone out even further considering that we can only see a little part of the universe since its expanding faster than light can travel meaning everything behind that horizon - if you want to call it like that - is completely invisible and once it becomes visible, you gotta consider you are seeing light that got emitted right after the big bang - so basically you could see the universe at its birth at this horizon.
So its actually not only the concept of position thats relative but also the concept of time. And to make this even more bizarre. Even the concept of length and mass depend on where you look at it from. A body around you moving faster becomes heavier. It gains mass just through motion - but of course only from positions which view this mass as moving. The mass from its own perspective stands still and you are the one becoming heavier moving around it. So gravity doesnt actually get messed up by this concept of relative mass. But it gives light a mass which can be sucked in by black holes (which is what makes them black). Ever wondered WHY you cant travel faster than light? Its because the mass of the viewed as moving body increases as it gets closer to the speed of light. Mass increases at a rate of: m(relative)=m(resting)*(1/sqrt(1-v²/c²)). So m approaces infinity as v gets bigger. A bigger mass needs more kinetic energy to get faster by the same amount (v=m*v²/2). By the way (do not push v to c or beyond c in your calculations because you will get no real results (complex ones to be exact) or just undefined ones if v=c. But at least the total amount of |v| would be equal to infinity if v=c. Which makes sense - so Traveling at the speed of light with a resting mass would require infinite energy. So no resting mass can travel at the speed of light since you cant have infinite energy. However - traveling at these speeds will not increase your mass from your perspective if you are the one traveling. Actually You will just see everyone else become contracted in length in your moving direction. So depending on where you view and measure your distance from you can travel a 1ly distance in just 5 minutes depending on where you view in from. Everyone who is staying home will see that you traveled just over a year. You yourself will notice that the distance became a lot shorter from your perspective so you easily traveled it in 5 minutes - FROM YOUR PERSPECTIVE.
Albert Einsteins relativity is a brilliant theory that feels even more brilliant once its understood.

Well done video, but I think you may need a follow up. Your main point was that there is no absolute reference frame, and that the idea of there being a center of a universe is very arbitrary.

But I'm seeing a lot of viewers who seem to think that there is an absolutely reference. That we are all moving in space away from the center of the Big Bang.

Or that a time machine that teleports us through time would leave us in empty space, because the Earth isn't in the same position anymore. Which is silly, because position is all relative in the first place - as you said, there is no such thing as an absolute position.

Explaining our movement in space based on various frames of reference was beautifully illustrated. But it unfortunately led people to believe this movement was absolute and not actually relative.

I would really love to see another video on the topic.

This is actually a false statement.
Lets assume we have a sphere with a vaccume, you can still tell the position of things within space via coordinates.
And if you move your imaginary point within the sphere, which is totally empty, you will still technically have movement.
So yes, even without matter, absolute positioning exists.
We can mark specific points.
We can absolutely "staple" something to space time.

You can be in a position in relation to the universe.
It simply requires an outside obsever to actually tell you your relative position in the universe.
But mathematically with the right tools we can absolutely tell you your absolute position in the universe.
Just like we can within a sphere which has no content.

Please, do correct me if I'm wrong. Not a physicist.

This is one of the things I think people don't consider when they're talking about whether time travel should be possible or not. If you were to travel through time, even just a nanosecond, with the earth scooting along through space at a million km/h would have you falling from an unsurvivable height back to earth. If you went back or forward in time by 1 second, you'd appear out in space somewhere behind or in front of the earth, unless you move through time AND space, and I think if you were able to open a portal to 1 second ago, you'd just be sucked through it into the vacuum of space.

You could have also discussed, why the the rings of Saturn, the solar system... are flat. Why are all the planets in one plain, instead of circling the sun in every direction (it has something to with how how all spinning things adjust to the same level.) Or why all the planets circle the sun in the same direction, except for Pluto.

There is no true "location," but there does seem to be a true "motion." Something in motion has energy, right? So is there an absolute measure of said motion? Things at rest within the gravity of a system (such as a rock on Earth) are generally thought of as lacking such energy, but if the Earth suddenly stopped or changed direction in some way, everything on it would shoot off, because it's not that they aren't in motion, but that their motion is in sync with the Earth.
Imagine being able to measure that theoretical "absolute motion." To tell the exact movement that something is experiencing at any given time.

all stars are in elliptical orbits in galaxies. disk-galaxies just have a dominant angular momentum, where all minor other angular momentums quickly cancelled each other out agains the dominant one, to remain. spherical galaxies just tend to lack mass, are dimmer, and that makes stars smaller and age slower, so less momentum is exchanged over time (less supernovae over time)

Spiral arms are just places, where more ellipses overlap. spiral arms have a much higher chance of a deadly supernovae nearby in long terms.
The Sun is in a good spot for 2 reasons:
- its elliptical orbit is not very eccentric, alsost a circle.
- it is in a minor side arm (and the local neighborhood of that side-armis weirdly special, a minor outlier)
- it orbits the sun at roughtly the same speed as the excentricity of the bigger spiral arms (the ellipses rotate over time, spinning the denser spiral arms around), so it never enters a deadly traffic-jam of an area, where nearby supernovar are more likely.

As always, a great job, thanks. I must point out, though, at 3:45, that the wobbling motion of the Earth by the Moon is wrong. It is not that the Moon pulls the Earth but they both pull at each other making them a system where they both rotate around their common center of mass. It is not, as shown, that the Moon pulls the Earth away from the elliptical orbit the Earth would have had without the Moon. Thus, in a simple animation, it would look as if the Moon pushes the Earth away. It would have been better depicted with a line, representing the mutual pull, with a dot about 1/6 the mutual distance closer to the Earth, with that dot traveling along the elliptical orbit and the Earth and the Moon rotating around that dot.

Loving the explanation of how we move in the universe. It also helps explain why simple time travel is useless; you’d need to move through both space and time for it to work.

The reason being, the matter that makes up the universe will NEVER be in the place that it was before you started reading this, and won’t be in the same place either when you finish it. In fact, it’s already past that point as well.

Because of that, movies like Back to the Future wouldn’t be possible because 30 years in the past or into their future, the Earth and indeed everything that ever existed, wouldn’t have been where it was in 1985. Doc & Marty would’ve likely just found themselves in the vacuum of space if they simply travel to the same location but elsewhere in time. Shows like Dr Who, whilst are still far fetched with the story lines, at least allow the Dr and co to travel through both time and space to account for this. Whether the writers knew this or not is another question, but it at least goes to explain a little as to why any form of time travel using machines is going to be rather tricky.

Why is it tricky? Trying to calculate where we are in the galaxy isn’t a simple task but doable. Then throw in the speed at which we’re travelling through the universe AND the precise rate at which the universe is expanding (or otherwise), then that calculation isn’t going to be easy.

This reminds me of my meditation method, but in reverse.

I find it helpful to define my "here" by playing forward time from the big bang forward, including the condensation of quantum fields that make up the mechanics of particles, up through the expansion of space, nucleation of protons and neutrons, collapse of hydrogen into helium, formation of all the natural elements by means of cosmic events, formation of galaxy supercluster groups along dark matter filaments, formation of those clusters and the galaxies they're made of, the formation of solar systems...then I dive down through those groups and clusters, to where we are: At the boonies of the Laneakaea supercluster, in a small cluster of galaxies, in the boonies of our own galaxy, in a solar system where we are not a pale blue dot. Then I quickly play through the history of life on the planet, and the history of humanity, before flying down from orbit to see my state, county, city, neighborhood, house, through my roof, into my room, then into my own head, where my thoughts become calm.

That exercise is...extremely good for clearing my head. Always, always always works. Highly recommend, though you do have to learn the details to visualize it all properly.

If speed can only be relative to something, and the speed of light is the fastest there is, what is the speed of light? In pursue of any answer I found the video of Veritasium "Why No One Has Measured The Speed Of Light". Assuming the speed of light is the limit, then if we send a light pulse off a flight space ship going e.g. 0.01c, then this impulse is still going at the speed of c. Assuming this is true, then after knowing that everything is moving relatively to everything, then it would be possible to determine the speed of absolute zero. Unless the space-time is also moving according to heavy objects? And c is relative to the current space-time. After this short investigation of my own, I'm thrilled about this topic, I hope it gets your attention as well.
P.S.
If we would manage to measure the one-way speed of light, then it could be our greatest clue to the Theory of Everything.

I think about this sometimes.

Even though we think the earth "goes around" the sun like a bus that repeats the same route indefinitely, the fact is that both the sun and the earth are moving together through the galaxy, and that galaxy is itself moving away from the original Big Bang's coordinates.

We are traveling through the infinity of space, and we never occupy the same space twice. While I typed these words our world has moved a huge distance away from the center of the universe, like a ripple in a pond. It is a terrifying and exhilarating thought, that absolutely nothing is fixed in place, that it's all hurtling towards some other place at a breakneck speed.

The comment that without "things" in the Universe, the concept of location makes no sense also works for time. Without "things" to measure the passage of time, the entire concept ceases to have any meaning. So when people talk about what existed (if anything) "before" the Universe, remember that Spacetime has no meaning without objects in it. A Trillion years or a millisecond are all the same if you have no way to count how long either is.

I love this video because I’ve been trying to explain to other people that even if interstellar travel were possible, that it would be impossible to to map out the stars, or your home planet location, because everything is always moving away from each other. So a perceived position in time and space only exists for the brief second that we process the light that reaches our eyes.  So the space ship would return to a completely different empty space. So we’re pretty much bound to travel within our solar system so we can depend on the consistency of local gravitational pull.

Here's a suggestion for another video topic since i think it fits this one perfectly.
Time Travel theories always suggest "when" in time but I haven't seen anyone discuss / clarify about "where" as well. As we know, we are moving in the space along with not only our Solar system but also the whole Galaxy. Suppose we finally know how to time travel and if we want to go 100 years "back in time", won't we also have to factor "where" exactly in the space our planet was 100 years ago? We can't just disappear and then reappear at the SAME place and be 100 years "back in time" when planet Earth would be millions of miles away from that place.

Maybe I am wrong thinking about time travel this way but whatever little I've read about those theories, it always involve physics and math. If anyone can clarify this in the comments, please feel free to! Maybe it's not as "complicated" and almost impossible as I think it to be. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Edit: And oh by the way, if there is some truth in my understanding, doesn't it further makes it almost impossible to time travel? Since we also have to find a way to travel millions of miles to get to the exact same spot in the space where Earth was 100 years ago and that's like travelling multiple times faster than the speed of light. 🤔🤔

"Do not look to the stars as an escape from life. Do not look at the prospect of space travel as a wonderful adventure into uncharted and uninhabited regions. Do not think that you can go anywhere you want and that you will develop over time a technology for traveling quickly through all the dimensions of life, zipping around the universe as if it were your own neighborhood. Do not think your conveyances will take you anywhere you want in the blink of an eye. Such notions are to be expected from young races full of imagination and hopeful expectation. But they do not fit into the reality of life as it has evolved over a much longer period of time.

There are nations in your local universe that have been in existence for twenty or thirty thousand years. They have established a level of conformity that is very strict. They are not engaged in social innovation, and most of them have no notion of individual freedom whatsoever. You would find living within them to be extremely difficult, if not intolerable.

Free nations are rare and very distinct. They do not travel around trying to plant their flags in other worlds. If they engage in planetary commerce, it is to a very limited degree. And they do not welcome visitors to their worlds. They remain isolated and discreet and guard their boundaries very carefully."

A quote from Life in the Universe - Chapter 3: The Limits of Space Travel, a free online book by Marshall Vian Summers.
